message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Behavioral Game Theory
Paper Abstract: People deviate from the predictions of game theory in two systematic ways. They are not purely self-interested (they care about fairness and try to cooperate with others), and they do not always consider what other players will do before making choices. However, with experience, these deviations sometimes disappear. People learn when they can afford to be unfair and what others will do; their behavior often converges to a game-theoretic equilibrium. A behavioral game theory that explains the initial deviations (and their disappearance) could be useful, especially if the learning process is modeled carefully and better data are gathered.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about cooperation:

## Definition

Cooperation takes place when a group of organisms works or acts together for a collective benefit to the group as opposed to working in competition for selfish individual benefit.

## Biological and Evolutionary Perspective

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.(no content)Cooperation is common in non-human animals, with many organisms other than apes, such as fish, birds, and insects exhibiting cooperative behavior including teaching, helping, and self-sacrifice.(no content)Humans are biologically geared to ensuring survival by social instincts, as much of the food early human beings ate were hunted or gathered, aspects of cooperation that alone cannot be done.

## Human Significance

Every human achievement is actually reliant on the cooperation efforts that have been created by others, whether mundane achievements or the greatest achievements.(no content)Real life is not zero-sum, and our best prospects are usually in cooperative efforts.

## Cooperation in Business

A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".(no content)Worker cooperatives are typically more productive and economically resilient than many other forms of enterprise, with twice the number of co-operatives (80%) surviving their first five years compared with other business ownership models (44%).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation"},{"title":"Shanghai Cooperation Organisation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation"},{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Islamic Summit of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Summit_of_the_Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation"},{"title":"Japan International Cooperation Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_International_Cooperation_Agency"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Mekong–Ganga Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mekong–Ganga_Cooperation"},{"title":"Organisation of Islamic Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation"},{"title":"Regional Cooperation Council - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Cooperation_Council"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about cooperation:

## Definition

Cooperation takes place when a group of organisms works or acts together for a collective benefit to the group as opposed to working in competition for selfish individual benefit.

## Biological and Evolutionary Perspective

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.(no content)Cooperation is common in non-human animals, with many organisms other than apes, such as fish, birds, and insects exhibiting cooperative behavior including teaching, helping, and self-sacrifice.(no content)Humans are biologically geared to ensuring survival by social instincts, as much of the food early human beings ate were hunted or gathered, aspects of cooperation that alone cannot be done.

## Human Significance

Every human achievement is actually reliant on the cooperation efforts that have been created by others, whether mundane achievements or the greatest achievements.(no content)Real life is not zero-sum, and our best prospects are usually in cooperative efforts.

## Cooperation in Business

A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".(no content)Worker cooperatives are typically more productive and economically resilient than many other forms of enterprise, with twice the number of co-operatives (80%) surviving their first five years compared with other business ownership models (44%).

Web search results for query: "Nash Equilibrium"

Links: [{"title":"Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Manipulated Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulated_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Strong Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Talk:Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Epsilon-equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epsilon-equilibrium"},{"title":"Coalition-proof Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition-proof_Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Correlated equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlated_equilibrium"},{"title":"Nash equilibrium computation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium_computation"},{"title":"Mertens-stable equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mertens-stable_equilibrium"},{"title":"Markov perfect equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_perfect_equilibrium"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Nash Equilibrium:

## Definition

In game theory, a Nash equilibrium is a situation where no player could gain more by changing their own strategy (holding all other players' strategies fixed) in a game.

## Key Characteristics

Nash equilibrium is the most commonly used solution concept for non-cooperative games.(no content)Nash equilibrium is achieved when no player can improve their outcome by changing their decision, assuming the other players' choices remain unchanged.

## Historical Background

Nash equilibrium is named after American mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr. While the idea of Nash equilibrium dates back to the time of Cournot, who in 1838 applied it to his model of competition in an oligopoly, the contribution of Nash in his 1951 article "Non-Cooperative Games" was to define a mixed-strategy Nash equilibrium for any game with a finite set of actions and prove that at least one (mixed-strategy) Nash equilibrium must exist in such a game.

## Applications

The concept has been used to analyze hostile situations such as wars and arms races, how conflict may be mitigated by repeated interaction, to study to what extent people with different preferences can cooperate, and to study the adoption of technical standards, and the occurrence of bank runs and currency crises.

## Refinements

Game theorists have developed various refinements of Nash equilibrium, including strong Nash equilibrium, coalition-proof Nash equilibrium, correlated equilibrium, and others, each designed to address specific types of strategic interactions.

I've performed a web search for "Learning" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here are the key results:

## General Definition

Learning is the process of acquiring new understanding, knowledge, behaviors, skills, values, attitudes, and preferences.(no content)The ability to learn is possessed by humans, non-human animals, and some machines; there is also evidence for some kind of learning in certain plants.

## Types of Learning

Learning may occur as a result of habituation, or classical conditioning, operant conditioning or as a result of more complex activities such as play, seen only in relatively intelligent animals.(no content)Learning may occur consciously or without conscious awareness.

## Machine Learning

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Learning Styles

Learning styles refer to a range of theories that aim to account for differences in individuals' learning. However, although there is ample evidence that individuals express personal preferences on how they prefer to receive information, few studies have found validity in using learning styles in education.

## Learning Systems

A learning management system (LMS) is a software application for the administration, documentation, tracking, reporting, automation, and delivery of educational courses, training programs, materials or learning and development programs.

Web search results for query: "Game Theory"

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Focal point (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focal_point_(game_theory)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Game Theory:

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

John Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Applications and Recognition

It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.(no content)Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Game Theory:

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

John Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Applications and Recognition

It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.(no content)Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

Reinert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Reinert"},{"title":"2025 Bermudian general election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Bermudian_general_election"},{"title":"Progressive capitalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_capitalism"},{"title":"Equity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equity"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Fairness Economics:

## Definition

Economic fairness, or economic equity, is the construct of fairness in economics and justice in the distribution of wealth, resources, and taxation within a society.(no content)It refers to a condition where economic processes and their outcomes do not unduly favor or disadvantage any particular group or individual, attempting to balance economic disparities among different societal segments to promote a more inclusive and just society.

## Key Aspects

**Scope and Importance:**
Equity is a central issue in public sector economics and public policy, and is at the heart of almost all economics policy debates, underscoring its integral role in shaping public decisions that impact overall societal welfare.

**Measurement and Dimensions:**
Equity looks at the distribution of capital, goods, and access to services throughout an economy and is often measured using tools such as the Gini index.(no content)According to Peter Corning, there are three distinct categories of substantive fairness (equality, equity, and reciprocity) that must be combined and balanced in order to achieve a truly fair society.

**Taxation:**
The role of equity in taxation is pivotal, as an equitable tax system aims to distribute the financial burden fairly across different income groups, ensuring that everyone contributes their fair share towards public services.

**Challenges:**
Defining equity presents inherent challenges due to its subjective nature, which depends heavily on societal values and individual perceptions of what is considered fair, as economists often struggle to establish a universally accepted definition of distributional equity.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of the analysis:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper proposes a new behavioral game theory framework that explains systematic deviations from classical game theory predictions and models the learning process.

**Extracted Triples (5 total):**

1. **Game theory** (concept) - uses - The paper builds on classical game theory concepts and deviations from their predictions.

2. **Economic fairness** (concept) - uses - Fairness is identified as a key reason people deviate from purely self-interested behavior.

3. **Cooperation** (concept) - uses - The paper discusses how people attempt to cooperate with others despite self-interest predictions.

4. **Learning** (concept) - proposes - The paper proposes carefully modeling the learning process through which behavioral deviations disappear.

5. **Nash equilibrium** (concept) - uses - The paper explains how behavior converges to game-theoretic equilibrium through learning.

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED - All 5 triples have been validated with correct Wikipedia URLs, entity types, and relations.

Sources:
- [Game theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory)
- [Economic fairness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_fairness)
- [Cooperation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation)
- [Learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning)
- [Nash equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium)
